title: Does nothing exist? Not as in no thing but does nothing exist within the everything that comprises the universe? Is nothing even possible? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, “nothing” definitely exists—as long as we’re not confusing “nothing” with “nothingness.” All you need for finding “nothing” are two things: a specified location, and an unambiguous definition of what would comprise “something” that needs to be completely missing from there. In short, unless we set our parameters—which is the basis of definition—we have no basis for sharing meaning, which is the basis of communication; we cannot answer the question. Now, that’s going to be vague and subject to being misunderstood without specific illustrations or examples. So let’s look at a few . . .  Nothing in the Box  This is simple enough. If you were unpacking after a move, and had taken everything out of a box, and someone asked, “What’s left in that box?” you might legitimately say, “Nothing.” And the person who asked you that, and likely anyone else in the room, would understand what you meant—though you didn’t count the air in the box, the dust in the box, the microscopic creatures in the box, or the tiny bits of styrofoam from the packing peanuts at the bottom of the box. There’s “nothing” in the box, because what qualifies as “something” is readily understood by all involved. Sure, somebody trying to be a particular “body hole” could take you to task on the air, the dust, the tiny critters, the styrofoam, and other “things” still in the box. But then they’re only trying to force the limited (and understood—even by them) scope of what qualifies as “something” in the apparent context of the exchange taking place. When people are honestly trying to communicate, they consent (either tacitly or directly expressed) to the arbitrary limits of time, location, physical presence, and purpose or intent. Only someone who is deliberately attempting to frustrate communication for whatever motives will remove all parameters and demand a definition that’s really “nothingness” instead just “nothing.” But “nothing” is a whole lot more than “nothingness”!  Nothing in Braces  If you’ve ever heard of “the empty set” in mathematics, enough said. But you also have punctuation. We can write using certain marks thus: “{},” “(),” and “[].” These have “nothing” in them. And you can see it! I literally see nothing!  Nothing in Mind  You ever say something within earshot of another person and they respond, “Huh? What did you say?” and you answer, “Oh, nothing.” Well, clearly, you said something. But you said nothing you meant for them to hear, or to hear clearly. Or you said nothing you’d care to repeat. Or nothing you care to explain. Or maybe someone mentions or tries to teach you a concept from science or some other subject or discipline, then asks you what you understood. “Nothing.” That lack of understanding—though made of “nothing” tangible or persistent—is comprised of the specific mental content not found in a specific locale: the person’s mind. We all (at least in most English speaking cultures) therefore understand the idiom someone might use when asked a question they have no answer for: “I got nothing.”  Nothing Up My Sleeve  There’s no trickery here. We all understand how language works. Nearly all words have multiple meanings and connotations. We are able to convey what we mean to others with enough care and effort. But people who have no problem understanding the latest slang, or the encrypted languages in certain subcultures (for example, rock and rap lyrics; fictional languages, such as Klingon, and elvish) will pretend not to understand the many mundane uses of the term nothing, in order to deliberately frustrate the communication process for one reason or another. We all know this, because we’ve all done it, myself included. And I’m not here to make any moral judgments about when and whether it’s okay to do this. I can think of situations where I think it would be unconscionable, including on Internet sites such as Quora. I would ask What is the intent? or Is it being used for a selfish or harmful purpose? Is this one of those times when it’s acceptable? I won’t presume to say. I leave it to the Reader to judge these things for yourself. Will you pretend not to understand what this answer is saying and thus take me to task over it? Or, will you realize that what I’m saying is nothing difficult or esoteric, and certainly nothing new? I like to say ‘the proof is in the question’, and in this case that sentiment is made explicit. My point here will appear trivial, but it is actually a space in itself. I want to give a sense of how significance is sensed. I want to show how we show things. Geo-metria is ‘the measure of the world’ - I want to delineate what shapes that.  ‘Nothing’ is a seven-letter word in English, amongst other things. In fact, it is those ‘other things’ that matter most. Obviously, nothing exists as a textual entity - an object within the universe. Yet, however, ‘nothing’ obviously does not mean nothing. It denotes absence - the antithesis of everything.  Yet in doing so we see ‘nothing’ expose the significance of significance. If there is something other than everything then that ‘everything’ is only identifiable according to everything else. Thus, nothing is bigger than everything.  An eye making itself. This only appears to be so because it doesn’t happen. It is a function of focus…but that is an operation dependent upon an eye… See how the grammar begins to operate in parallel? There are two antithetical interpretations of ‘nothing is bigger than everything’. Similarly, ‘nothing means nothing’ expresses both a literal tautology and invokes a reference to an invisible metaphysics in which the meaning of the term which allows it to function resides.  One of my favourite definitions of irony. I suppose if a dictionary had nothing here it would undermine the entire enterprise. In one way, this world of non-sense is the Platonic realm. In another way, many different realms seem to coexist in this manner - some of which Plato might not inhabit happily, since they would correspond to interpretations of even his words which he himself would not recognise. Is Plato’s vision of the Absolute absolute? Is the ‘Form of the Good’ unitary? That was, after all, Socrates’ idea. Are Plato and Socrates one and the same? Hmmm…  Listen to them. So, nothing most definitely exists because we can talk about it. Indeed, that existence is what facilitates our very discussion! There is freedom of interpretation in infinite senses, but only because nothing really establishes the effectiveness of relativity. There are always at least two ways to read things, and the reason for this is that reasoning can differ.  More irony. On both sides. Especially in the middle, given that it’s an answer. The way reason itself can be reasonably different is that the rationality that renders it is actually present as nothing. This is the logic of logic and the truth of truth. It it were not there then nothing could really denote anything. Because this is not so, it is actually the case: Consider this matrix:  What colour are the points where the axes intersect? Are they changing? In fact, they are because they’re constant. Significance is first and foremost an artefact of exclusion. As I began by saying (as if what I have said is sensible at all!) what is depends upon what is not. Nowhere is this more clearly seen than in photoreception. As Jess H. Brewer once remarked to me, photons can be their own antiparticles ‘because they have no overt properties’. How, therefore, would we know such things exist if their own properties are not necessarily evident? Well, those properties are revealed in the way that they reveal everything other than themselves.  Pictures of photons. They make me giggle. Mark my words (they cannot be defined exactly), light enlightens is in absentia. By the time we are aware of it a photon is no longer what it was - it has been incorporated into our mechanism of manifestation. Sometimes a physically-minded scientist will ask me how this applies to their laser instruments - I usually reflect on the question and ask whether the data is demonstrated on a screen.  The above image indicates phototransduction. To me, things like this are almost the epitome of abstract art. You are looking at what you are looking with. Can this really happen? So it is when we talk about nothing - the basis of belief itself becomes the standard of selection. Thus The Treachery of Images.  Nothing is the context of existence. In this way it is really everything and can refer to anything that is not the thing which is selected as ‘it’. Context is everything because nothing is contextual in itself. Nothing is a word defined by other words which themselves change as they adapt to different roles dictated by different contexts. In this way etymology is everything because nothing explains etymology - it is the blank page on which any script is set and the space for every sound.  Thus Truth is found in Paradox and revealed in Irony because ‘finding’ is active and ‘revelation’ is not. Everything is Ironic because nothing actually is. See what I mean? Possibly…but if and only if you possibly don’t. That’s the nature of probability. When one is what everything adds up to then nothing within that sum can be sufficiently summary. If all this computes then you can count on the fact that the answer is still missing - just like the punchline to a joke that wasn’t understood. It has already passed. But when I imagine something, or even actually see objects, I have got something which my neighbour has not."—I understand you. You want to look about you and say: "At any rate only I have got THIS."—What are these words for? They serve no purpose.— Can one not add: "There is here no question of a 'seeing'—and there- fore none of a 'having'—nor of a subject, nor therefore of T either"? Might I not ask: In what sense have you got what you are talking about and saying that only you have got it? Do you possess it? You do not even see it. Must you not really say that no one has got it? And this too is clear: if as a matter of logic you exclude other people's having something, it loses its sense to say that you have it. Ludwig Wittgenstein - Philosophical Investigations When will we get it? I imagine the answer is ‘in time’. Ironically, the point at which we do so will no longer be the present.

This is an ancient philosophical question that humanity has yet to answer definitively. The Greeks thought of it as the problem of “the void.” From a simple-minded perspective, it might seem there could be “space” with nothing “in” it, but you’d never be able to demonstrate this, because in order to measure that space, something would have to pass through it, like light. At a somewhat deeper level, there’s a question as to what “space-time” means. It can be thought of as just a placeholder between events, so it’s as close to “nothing” as we may be able to conceive. But whether that means it is “nothing” may not be answerable.
